text:
KELLY BOWMAN: The nature, the
innovation, the creativity.

You can experience it all with
a trip to the gem of the Pacific
Northwest, Seattle.

It wouldn't be a visit
to the Emerald City

without a stop at
the Space Needle.

Glass elevators whisk you 520
feet up to the observation

deck, where you'll experience
a 360-degree panorama

of the city, and some
new interactive features
for guests.

KAREN OLSON: We've totally
teched out the Space Needle.

So we added digital
experiences that are amazing.

So people not only
see the view, they
can interact with the view.

We have an app of
augmented reality.
We have virtual reality.

We have kiosks that
let you teleport
into amazing sites in the city.

So the Space Needle is all
about that, what's possible.

KELLY BOWMAN: You might
work up an appetite

from all that
teleporting, so grab

a bite to eat at a restaurant
with a unique spin.

KAREN OLSON: We have
Sky City restaurant.

You can sit and see
this amazing view,

and we have gorgeous
sunsets on the Sound.

KELLY BOWMAN: From
that vantage point,

you might spot the
mystical worlds
of Chihuly Garden and Glass.

The exhibit sits directly under
the Space Needle in the heart

of Seattle center, and
showcases the studio
glass of artist Dale Chihuly.

MICHELLE BUFANO: Dale Chihuly
is from the Northwest.

And there isn't a
glass experience
like this anywhere else.

Dale built this exhibition
from the ground up,

and that it's his vision
is so unique and so rare
that it really is a must-see.

KELLY BOWMAN: The
exhibition provides a look

at Chihuly's inspiration
and influences,

featuring eight
galleries, the centerpiece
glass house, and a lush garden.

MICHELLE BUFANO: If you
just want a little bit

of information about a
gallery, you can go and watch
a five-minute gallery talk.
Or we have longer tours.

KELLY BOWMAN: Another
tour you might enjoy

can be found just outside the
city at Theo Chocolate Factory.

DEBRA MUSIC: Theo Chocolate
is the first organic,

fair-trade-certified,
bean-to-bar chocolate
maker in all of North America.

And what is so cool
about visiting Theo

is that you get to
see how chocolate

is made all the
way from the bean
through to finished product.

You get to see our
confection kitchen,

where we make all kinds
of things by hand.

And you get to eat chocolate
all the way through.

KELLY BOWMAN: After the tour,
take a piece of Seattle home
with you.

DEBRA MUSIC: We have all
kinds of beautiful handmade
ganache and caramel and toffees.

We have a lot of special treats
you can only get in the store.

KELLY BOWMAN: Once you've
satisfied your sweet tooth,

head just 10 minutes up the road
to one of the most unique spots
in Seattle, the Ballard Locks.

Completed in 1917, the Locks
link the Puget Sound with Lake
Union and Lake Washington.

KATIE MCGILLVRAY: We'll get
about 45,000 vessels a year.

We're the busiest
lock in the nation.

You can see
recreational vessels,

commercial vessels,
fishermen, navy,
army, going through the Locks.

And then in the summertime,
if you're lucky,
you get to see the salmon--

the sockeye, the
chinook, the coho--
going through our fish ladder.

KELLY BOWMAN: Visitors
can also enjoy
walking along the grounds.

KATIE MCGILLVRAY: We have a
beautiful botanical garden

with over 500 different
species of plants and trees.

So that is pretty
unique in and of itself.

KELLY BOWMAN: From city streets
to bright blue waterways,

you can find a little
something for everyone
in beautiful Seattle.
Kelly Bowman, CNN.
